ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Optical detection of DNA translocation through silicon nanopore by ultraviolet light

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Graduate School of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: In this paper, we propose a new optical detection scheme for nanopore-based DNA sequencing with high resolution towards eventual base identification. We use ultraviolet light for excitation of a fluorescent probe attached to DNA and a nanopore in the silicon membrane that has a significantly large refractive index and an extinction coefficient at ultraviolet wavelengths. In this study, numerical electromagnetic simulation revealed that the z-polarization component (perpendicular to the membrane plane) of the electric field was dominant near the nanopore and generated a large electric field gradient at the nanopore exit, typically with a decay length of 2 nm for a nanopore with diameter of 7 nm. The large extinction coefficient contributed to reduction in background noise coming from fluorophore-labeled DNA strands that remain behind the membrane (the cis side of the membrane). We observed a high signal-to-noise ratio of single DNA translocation events under the application of an electric field.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Nanopore-based sensing is a versatile technique for single-molecule detection and an analysis method with broad applications in the field of biotechnology [1, 2]. One of the most attractive and promising applications is the development of single-molecule DNA sequencing technology, in which a single DNA strand threads through a pore in a thin membrane and the bases are identified [3, 4]. In most cases, individual base identification is performed by measuring either current flow through the membrane or tunneling current across the membrane, in both of which the chemical differences of the bases are detected [3, 5, 6]. Currently, there have been two major categories in nanopore technologies: synthetic solid-state nanopores and biological nanopores [7, 8]. Solid-state nanopores are fabricated in silicon nitride, silicon, graphene, and so on, with focused electron/ion beam or other techniques. Biological nanopores include proteins, such as the protein alpha hemolysin suspended on the lipid bilayer. Although both approaches offer significant potential for high resolution in single-base detection, challenges including the control of translocation speed through a nanopore and the possibility of multiplexed, parallel detection on a single device need to be addressed [9]. Typically, it takes only 1 ms for 10,000 base DNA to translocate through the pore [10]. At such a rate, however, it is difficult to detect the current alternation identifying individual bases with sufficient accuracy.

An optical readout scheme using a solid-state nanopore is a promising approach to address the drawbacks of current-based sequencing. A faster translocation rate is acceptable even in a single-photon counting mode for the detection of the fluorescence with which a DNA strand is functionalized as labels to identify each base. Parallel detection using a nanopore array can be easily implemented by employing a highly sensitive charge-coupled device, whose performance is expected further improvement. Concerning the spatial resolution required for sequence readout, Meller et al. proposed the use of specifically designed DNA polymers [11]. An individual nucleotide is converted into a oligonucleotide sequence (20 bases in a typical length) and hybridized to two-color beacons with two fluorescent probes attached (P1 and P2), whose permutations (P1–P1, P1–P2, P2–P1, and P2–P2) define the four bases. This technique allows the required single-base resolution (3.4 Å) to be reduced to approximately 5 nm (<3.4 Å × 20 bases). The resolution is still challenging but attainable.

In this paper, we propose a new optical detection scheme for nanopore sequencing with high resolution and signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio. We combine ultraviolet light for the excitation of a fluorescent probe and a nanopore in a silicon membrane, which has a large refractive index and extinction coefficient at ultraviolet wavelengths. Due to the large refractive index, the z-polarization component of the electric field is expected to generate a large electric field gradient at the nanopore exit. We observed a single-DNA translocation events under application of an electric field with a high S/N ratio owing to the large extinction coefficient, which suppresses the background noise from fluorophores in the cis side of the membrane.

Section2.Heading: Electrophoresis chamber
Section2.Para:
Figure 1 shows the experimental setup for our DNA observation. In order to observe DNA translocation events, a 10-nm-thick porous silicon membrane was inserted between two chambers, cis and trans. The average diameter of pores in the porous silicon membrane was 7 nm. The membrane was cleaned by a plasma ion bombarder (PIB-10, Shinku Device Co., Ltd.) and a hydrophilic layer was formed on it. Both chambers were subsequently filled with 1 M KCl with 10 mM Tris HCl. Ag/AgCl electrodes were immersed into each chamber and connected to a DC power supply. Applied voltages ranged from 100 to 200 mV (trans to cis). In the experiment, DNA samples were added to the cis chamber and translocated through the nanopore to the trans chamber.
Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of experimental setup. A fluorophore-labeled DNA strand that translocates through the nanopore in silicon membrane from the cis- to trans-chamber is excited with ultraviolet laser light

Section2.Heading: Optical setup
Section2.Para: As illustrated in Fig. 1, linearly polarized (x-polarized) Gaussian beam from a laser diode with a wavelength of 375 nm was focused onto the porous silicon membrane by using a water immersion objective (×60, 1.2 numerical aperture, Nikon). The incident laser power at the sample was 100 μW. The high numerical aperture yielded a significant longitudinal electric field component. According to Sick et al., the z-component of electric field, which is dominant at the membrane surface due to the high refractive index of silicon, generates a double-lobed spot, as described below [12]. Therefore, we utilized one of two lobes for observing DNA that translocate through the nanopore. Fluorescence from fluorophore-labeled DNA was detected with an avalanche photodiode (APD; Perkin Elmer, Inc.) after band-pass filtering. Pulse signals from the APD were counted by using a photon counter with an integration time of 0.5 ms and the time trace was captured by PC-based oscilloscope.

Section2.Heading: Sample preparation
Section2.Para: λ-DNA fragments (11933, 14321, 9533, and 12715 bp) were produced by incubating commercial λ-DNA (48 kbp long, Takara Bio, Inc.) with PuvI restriction enzyme for 2 h at 37 °C and for 10 min at 65 °C. The 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI) dihydrochloride was added to the solvent at room temperature in order to stain λ-DNA. Finally, the solvent with DAPI-modified λ-DNA was purified by Centri-Sep spin columns. From a spectroscopic measurement, the absorption and emission bands of DAPI-modified λ-DNA were observed at λ=300–400 nm and λ=400–600 nm, respectively.

Section2.Heading: FDTD simulation
Section2.Para:
In order to quantitatively confirm our optical method, we conducted a finite-difference time domain (FDTD) simulation for the model shown in Fig. 2(a). X-polarized Gaussian beam (λ=375 nm) was focused onto a 10-nm-thick Si membrane with 7-nm nanopores. Figure 2(b) shows the electric field intensity distribution. Due to the large refractive index and extinction coefficient of silicon at ultraviolet wavelengths, the transmission of light to the cis-side of membrane is negligible. This contributes to the suppression of background fluorescence from fluorophore-labeled DNA strands.
Fig. 2
Model used for the FDTD simulation and the results obtained in the simulation. (a) Model for FDTD simulation. (b) Electric field intensity distribution. (c) Electric field intensity profile along the dotted line in (b)

The result of our numerical simulation showed that the z-component electric field at the membrane surface is dominant compared to the x-component due to the boundary condition at the silicon surface. The z-component forms double-lobed light spots, whose intensity is significantly reduced inside the membrane also due to the boundary condition. Although previous studies predicted that the electric field was transmitted through a nanopore with diameter of 200 nm [13], our numerical simulation showed that nanopores of diameter 7 nm were small enough to reduce the penetration of the electric field. Therefore, a considerably large gradient of the electric field was achieved at the exit of nanopores in our experimental setup. Figure 2(c) is a plot of electric field intensity (z-component) along the dotted line in Fig. 2(b). In the plot, the electric field rises steeply in 2 nm, which corresponds to the resolution to read out the sequence of fluorophore that labels DNA. In our scheme, when the fluorophore molecule attached to DNA passes through the nanopore, the fluorophore is excited by the light field with a steep gradient. After this process, we assume that the fluorophore is photobleached immediately before the next neighboring fluorophore reaches the excitation volume. Therefore, the x-component, which is localized separately at the point far from the nanopore, does not play any role in the excitation of fluorophore. For these points, we can conclude that the z-component electric field rising steeply in 2 nm is sufficient for the sequencing of designed DNA polymer mentioned above.

Section2.Heading: DNA translocation
Section2.Para:
Next, we experimentally observed DNA translocation events. Figure 3, (a) and (b), shows typical photon burst traces of fluorophore-labeled DNA strands that passed through the nanopore for applied voltage ΔV of 100 and 200 mV, respectively. The fluorophore emits photons while it translocates through the nanopore and then traverses the excitation volume. For most of the events, the photon burst lasted less than 0.5 ms (the integration time of photon counting). A histogram of the burst amplitude (the number of detected photon counts per burst) for the measurement time of 3 min is shown in Fig. 3(c). In the case of ΔV=200 mV, photon bursts with a smaller amplitude increased significantly compared to that of ΔV=100 mV.
Fig. 3
The results obtained from the observation of the translocation events. (a), (b) Photon burst traces of the translocation events for applied voltage ΔV of 100 and 200 mV, respectively. (c) Histogram of the burst amplitude (the number of detected photon counts per burst) for the measurement time of 3 min

A change in drag force should be responsible for this voltage dependence [14]. In the vicinity of membrane surface, the electric field concentrates on the nanopore and gives rise to the drag force that captures DNA into and ejects it from the nanopore. The drag force is effective in the capture radius r ∗, within which the electrophoretic speed exceeds the diffusion speed. According to Eq. (1) in Ref. [15], we estimated r ∗ to be 2.3 μm for ΔV=100 mV, which indicates that the excitation volume was contained within the capture volume (see also Fig. 2(b) and (c)). Since r ∗ and electrophoretic force are proportional to ΔV, the increase in ΔV leads to the enhancement of capture frequency and the reduction in translocation time through the nanopore and transit time through the excitation volume.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In this paper, we presented a new optical detection approach for nanopore-based DNA sequencing with high resolution. We proposed to use ultraviolet light for excitation of a fluorescent probe attached to DNA and a nanopore in the silicon membrane. Due to the large refractive index and extinction coefficient of silicon at ultraviolet wavelengths, z-polarization component of the electric field was dominant in the vicinity of the nanopore and generated a large electric field gradient at the nanopore exit. The numerical simulation revealed that the electric field rise steeply in 2 nm for a 7-nm nanopore. The large extinction coefficient caused a reduction in the background noise coming from fluorophore-labeled DNA strands in the cis side of the membrane. We demonstrated high signal-to-noise ratio detection of single DNA translocation events and discussed its dependence on the applied electric field.
